questions.text: When you are confronted with a clear injustice:

answers.text: You step in immediately, even if you don't fully understand the situation.
You act if you believe your intervention can genuinely change the outcome.
You are deeply affected, but you know you cannot always intervene.
You believe the world is full of injustice, and not all of it is your responsibility.

questions.text: When you witness someone else's suffering:

answers.text: You feel it almost as if it were your own.
You acknowledge it, but keep emotional distance to remain effective.
It affects you, but you prefer not to stay exposed to it for too long.
You prefer not to become emotionally involved.

questions.text: When acting involves a real personal risk:

answers.text: You accept the risk if it can prevent unjust suffering.
You take the risk only if it is rationally justified.
You hesitate, even if the situation deeply affects you.
You avoid situations where the personal cost is too high.

questions.text: When you choose not to act:

answers.text: You experience it as a personal failure.
You accept it if it is the most coherent decision.
You feel a lasting sense of guilt.
You see no particular issue with it.

questions.text: When facing a complex and violent situation:

answers.text: You want to understand it in order to intervene.
You want to understand it to make the best possible decision.
You want to understand it, even if you don't act.
You don't believe everything needs to be fully understood.

questions.text: What would make you step back permanently:

answers.text: Becoming complicit in an injustice.
Acting without certainty about the consequences.
Losing emotional control over yourself.
Sacrificing your own balance for something beyond you.
